creditline: Gift of funds from the Regis Corporation
description: Rare black-ground thanka features the ferocious protective deity Vajrabhairava locked in cosmic embrace with his sakti, or female counterpart; he tramples birds, animals, demons and Hindu deities underfoot; his thirty-two secondary hands radiate around him, holding attributes; he wears garlands of severed human heads, skulls, and a five-skull tiara; central figures encircled by manifestations of the guardian Mahakala.
medium: Opaque colors and gold on cotton
text: Death is a major subject of Tibetan painting, and this black-ground thangka would have serves as method of meditating on the subject for an advanced practitioner. The central deity, Vajrabhairava, is in his most ferocious form
title: Vajrabhairava
